questions.question: What is React Native?
options: A web framework for building websites
A framework for building mobile applications using React
questions.explanation: React Native is a framework for building mobile applications using React. Instead of rendering to the web browser's DOM, React Native renders to native mobile components.

questions.question: What is the key difference between React (Web) and React Native?
options: React (Web) renders to DOM; React Native renders to native mobile components
questions.explanation: React (Web) renders to the DOM (HTML elements), while React Native renders to native mobile components (iOS UIView or Android View). Both use the same React concepts, but the underlying rendering is completely different.

questions.question: What do React (Web) and React Native have in common?
options: They use the same components (div, button, etc.)
They use the same core React concepts (components, props, state, hooks, JSX)
They both use CSS for styling
questions.explanation: Both React (Web) and React Native use the same core React concepts: components, props, state, hooks (useState, useEffect, useContext, etc.), and JSX syntax. The main differences are in rendering targets and styling approaches.

options: Uses `onPress` instead of `onClick`, and `style` prop takes a JavaScript object instead of a CSS string
questions.explanation: React Native uses `onPress` instead of `onClick`, and the `style` prop takes a JavaScript object (StyleSheet) instead of a CSS string. There's no `className` prop in React Native.

questions.question: What is Expo?
options: A framework and platform built on top of React Native that makes mobile development easier
questions.explanation: Expo is a framework and platform built on top of React Native that makes mobile development easier. It provides features like Expo Router, Expo Go, and pre-built SDK modules for common device features.

questions.question: What are the benefits of using Expo?
options: No native code required, easy setup, built-in features, fast development
questions.explanation: Expo provides: no native code required (write JavaScript/TypeScript only), easy setup (works on Windows, Mac, and Linux), built-in features (camera, location, file system, etc.), and fast development with hot reload.

questions.question: What is Expo Router?
options: A file-based routing system where the folder structure in the `app/` directory determines your app's navigation and screens
questions.explanation: Expo Router is a file-based routing system where the folder structure in the `app/` directory determines your app's navigation and screens. For example, `app/(tabs)/courses.tsx` creates a courses screen, and `app/(tabs)/courses/[id].tsx` creates a dynamic route for individual courses.

questions.question: What is Expo Go?
options: An app that allows you to test React Native apps on real devices without building
questions.explanation: Expo Go is a mobile app (available on iOS App Store and Google Play) that allows you to test React Native apps on real devices without building. You can scan a QR code to load your app instantly.

questions.question: What is React Native Paper?
options: A Material Design 3 component library for React Native
questions.explanation: React Native Paper is a Material Design 3 component library for React Native. It provides pre-built, styled components that follow Google's Material Design guidelines.

options: How to use CSS in React Native
How to write platform-specific code for iOS vs. Android
questions.explanation: This demonstrates platform-specific code. Sometimes you need different code for iOS vs. Android. The `Platform.OS` property allows you to check which platform the app is running on and adjust behavior accordingly.

questions.question: How is navigation different in mobile apps compared to web apps?
options: Mobile apps use URLs and browser navigation
Mobile apps use stack navigation (push/pop screens), tab navigation (bottom tabs), and drawer navigation (side menu)
questions.explanation: Web apps use URLs and browser navigation. Mobile apps use different navigation patterns: stack navigation (push/pop screens like browser history), tab navigation (bottom tabs like browser tabs), and drawer navigation (side menu). Expo Router handles this with file-based routing.

questions.question: Why are many mobile APIs async?
options: Because it's a new trend in mobile development
Reading from storage, making network requests, and accessing device features (camera, location) are I/O bound operations
Mobile APIs don't support synchronous operations
questions.explanation: Many mobile APIs are async because they involve I/O operations: reading from storage, making network requests, and accessing device features (camera, location). Always use `async/await` or `.then()` when working with these APIs.

questions.question: What is the tech stack used in this course for mobile development?
options: React Native, Expo, Expo Router, React Native Paper, TypeScript, React Query, Fetch API
questions.explanation: The tech stack includes: React Native (core framework), Expo (development platform), Expo Router (file-based routing), React Native Paper (UI component library), TypeScript (type safety), React Query (data fetching and caching), and Fetch API (native HTTP client).

questions.question: If you know React for web, what percentage of React Native knowledge do you already have :)?
questions.explanation: If you know React for web, you're already 80% there! The React concepts (hooks, state, props, context) are exactly the same. The main differences are: components (use Paper instead of HTML), styling (use StyleSheet instead of CSS), navigation (use Expo Router instead of React Router), and platform APIs (use Expo SDK instead of browser APIs).

questions.question: What does React Native NOT use?
questions.explanation: React Native doesn't use HTML or CSS. Instead, it uses React Native components (View, Text, etc.) and styles with JavaScript objects (StyleSheet API) or component library props (like Paper's `mode="contained"`).
